medical_history.chief_complaint: Progressive weakness, hypotonia, nystagmus, and hearing loss.
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: The patient was born healthy at full term. At 3 months, he developed vomiting and failure to thrive, diagnosed with renal tubular acidosis (RTA). At 12 months, he developed horizontal nystagmus. At 30 months, he experienced leg pain, progressive weakness of lower and then upper extremities, dysarthria, decline in language skills, and sensorineural hearing loss after a mild viral illness. Examination at 30 months showed weakness (4/5 muscle strength), hypotonia, and a wide-based gait. By 53 months, findings included bilateral wrist drop, finger contractures, decreased muscle bulk, and microcephaly (head circumference at 2nd percentile).
medical_history.past_medical_history: Renal tubular acidosis diagnosed at 3 months of age.
medical_history.family_history: Parents were first cousins; the family history included four unaffected older siblings and the maternal grandmother had multiple miscarriages. An older sister had a child with microcephaly of undetermined cause.
